text: thank you so much for having me here i was a grad student back in the day in the audience like some of you so it's
really fun to be upfront um all right so i'm going to start with a
kind of high level call to action this is sort of like a kind of inspirational talk if you will and i give you like a
wild tour through a lot of the work we do but i wanted to read you a couple of quotes from sort of pundits in academia
and also in industry so here's tristan harris we're training and conditioning
a whole new generation of people that when we're uncomfortable or lonely or uncertain or afraid we have a digital
pacifier for ourselves that's kind of atrophying our own ability to deal with that and for those of you who don't know who
he is he used to be a design ethicist at google and now he runs this place called the center for humane technology
and that's actually a quote from the movie the social dilemma which maybe some of you seen on netflix which is sort of a dystopian take on what social
media is doing here's a couple of quotes from sherry turkle she is an academic at mit
this is from recon reclaiming conversation intelligence once meant more than what
any artificial intelligence does it used to include sensibility sensitivity awareness discernment reason
acumen and wit and then another quote from a different book of hers alone together
these days insecure in our relationships and anxious about intimacy we look to
technology for ways to be in relationships and protect ourselves from them at the same time
so i want to be clear that i am not a luddite okay i don't want us all to go
back to running through the fields and talking with tin cans and you know i know like i'm no longer a super young
person so i just want you to know this critique is not coming from a kind of luddite point of view
but i do think that technology has sort of slid into this sinkhole
of sucking our individual attention into screens and kind of proliferating these
opportunities for us to kind of fall down these rabbit holes and sometimes those rabbit holes lead to the illusion
that we're having rich meaningful connection with each other when when we climb up out of them we realize wow
there's something missing in this it's not as rich as it could be i'm not even sure what's wrong but something's going on
and i care about this so i have worked in industry i've worked in design firms i worked at a startup at one point
and i'm in academia now and my perspective on what we can do in the academy is that we can take
the long view we can consciously choose to chart a different course if we like
from situations we see unfolding in technology so uh there are other people here at
stanford who do that kind of thing one person that comes to mind for me is michael bernstein who's a faculty member
in this program who is you know really taking sort of society and ethics bull by the horns and
thinking about his own work in social computing so i think especially engineering
schools we exist at this really interesting intersection between practicality in the world of making
things that are going to go out and affect potentially millions of people but also doing basic research that can
subtly shift the course of where we all go and i think it's important to reflect on that and think about what we can do what our
positionality is basically in affecting the future of technology and that's basically what this talk is about in
some sense so of course there are a lot of different ways to do that so sometimes technologists also get
involved in policy and advising however at least for me the primary
tools of my trade of influencing the direction of where things go
are a combination of building technological prototypes of possible futures and also distilling out lessons from
building those prototypes and testing them out with real people to create tools for thought for other
people not just in research but also out in industry
now i use the p word i use the play word i know christina's bought into that
i'm going to introduce some tools for thought today and i include play in the mix and
i know that for some people i think this country in particular still has this kind of puritan
work ethic background and there's sometimes a suspicion of games and play is maybe like a waste of time
maybe something sidelined or smaller than serious weighty problems of the world and i hope part of what will
happen in this talk is you'll see how play has become an important through line for me in understanding the future of where
technology could go in a different way
this is my lab group this is a failed kayaking expedition we took as a field trip uh

when we design our technology so

anybody know who donna haraway is she's this like old school media theorist like basically a goddess of uc

tease apart what is this creepy thing i think has been happening with technology i was like
it's too isolating it's too individualistic this is bugging me but what if i flip that what if it's the
opposite so i'm gonna i'm gonna set up this juxtaposition for you so right now we have this value that the
device is there to support me at my convenience and serve information perfectly adapted to me
it's kind of like my perfect companion right we just take that for granted but what if devices were there to
support us to support the space between us collectively toward a shared experience what was that
what if that was the primary driving value you took when you designed something also the device can ask for as much of
it my attention as it wants at any time it can make me stare at it and touch it and ignore others
it's like a horrible spoiled like pet or something it's kind of awful if you start thinking it that way but what if
devices were deeply sensitive to not interrupting and rather enhancing my experience with
other people around me and actually was able to avoid those eruptions what if their signaling and input
these devices didn't get in the way maybe it even added something to my
social experience is that too much to ask maybe it's not right
right now we have this thing like devices are like tribbles they're just they're just just more and more and more and more of them and everybody buy more
buy more buy more so more devices is better everybody needs their own and each person should have all the functionality
like nobody should think of like old technology like an apple press or a cotton gin people like come from
miles to use this device they would form relationships they would learn about things they could help each
other with what if sharing devices was fine and maybe even to be desired
because it's powerful to have interdependent and distinct and unique things sometimes so what if we operated
with that assumption and then the last one is we this is especially most recently there's this
hidden assumption it's always okay for my device to collect data about me toward farming
aggregate patterns to sell better stuff to me as an individual or to other individuals like me wherever
they are at some future time but what if we said no our devices should only use data they
collect about us to improve our co-present experience right here in the here and now
right not to say to like rigorously stick to these but to set up this juxtaposition to help you see kind of
the way i was trying to explode out this design space yeah how about improving your experience in the future
that would be fine too i think but it's sort of like
i so i person this is a sidebar but i personally think a lot of what's messing with human relations right now
is the weird um endless presence of things people say if you think of twitter
so there's a way and i've and i saw this great piece ezra klein interviewed this woman who was very astute in her use of
different media forms she said she would only have complex arguments on podcasts
because it's a lot harder to strip out and reflect words you can do it but it takes more effort
and people are lazy so they'd rather retweet a tweet so it's a good question but i think it's

i'm going to show you two research through lines to give you examples of how taking those juxtapositions into
account shapes the kind of work we do and how we think about what we're trying to do in the world and
kind of show you how that evolves and ends up providing tools for thought as well
and i should say right now the approach we take in our lab i already said we're tinkerers
we build things with other people's stuff we take what is called a research through design approach
so we believe very much in knowledge being produced through bottom-up making that we learn as we go but we also
believe in the importance of abstracting knowledge that makes it easier to share so a lot of times we end up with what is
called mid-range theory that we're sharing in papers like strong concepts or sometimes we show a portfolio of our
work and we do what's called an annotated portfolio but i just want you to understand the kind of work we do all right
and then i want to say one more thing about why play so probably those of you who have taken
a games class know about the magic circle that huizinga talked about
which is that when we engage in a place situation with others
we agree to step a little bit outside of ourselves and to accept a different reality consensually and together for a
little bit and i think this is a really nice way of thinking about
shaping different socio-technical configurations even if you're not explicitly designing a game
and i think it's a very valuable place to look for because when we design a new social technology
we have to get people to to take it up and we have to understand what it's like when they take it up you know i think a
classic example would be google glass they did this thing where they like you had to like apply to get one and they
distributed them really broadly across lots of random people all over they didn't create little pockets of kind of
power quirky users of glass to help them understand bottom up what was going to happen they weren't thinking of the
social space around the technology so i think thinking about games and play helps us
to design this whole nexus of things and i have a paper about that from a couple of years about at kai and all along i
will be sign posting papers and i will share these slides so you can always track them down later
okay so the first strand of work i'm going to talk about is our social wearables work
so when we got into this um you know i don't mind fitbits this is just you know being a little dramatic here but
most of the commercially successful wearables were like oh i'm tracking all this data about me how many steps have i

watch and other similar things it's like you can pick up phone or text messages right but it's sort of social media
stuff so we're like what if we played around with social wearables
and thought about these social values like could we come up with a really different design space around this stuff
so as i said before i was at uc santa cruz i was actually at nyu and one of my part of my joint appointment was in the

who here does not know what larp is okay a couple of people so this is like it's not like theater
because there's no audience it's like more like a game of d where somebody's like the dungeon master
they're larp designers and they facilitate a shared experience and people come together they get a
character they're improvising but there are also these plot points and these kind of emotional buildups
so i knew about larp and i was really fascinated by this community one of the cool things about them is they're very
particular about how they use technology so we actually did this paper for ftg a few years ago like his
foundational work before we got into this design phase and one of the things about larp is they
will not use a technology that distracts people no phones no watches like
they will only use the technology and here's some pictures from the survey we did about different technology they will
custom build really elaborate wonderful things but they have to support the group experience of being in this interesting
story world
so we went through two cycles of co-design with larp designers and then deploying
devices in their larps and in doing that we got a lot of rich information from them
about like what affordances of technology work socially like what do they signal to
other people how how do they work with a person as they're very engaged in a narrative situation
i'm going to show you a little video about one of those pieces this was the second in the cycle this was so when i actually when i first

and i had this fantasy of people running around with technology in the woods i was like
i'm gonna like make a larp thing here you know it's just like one of those first thoughts as a researcher so i was like yes
so we found this group event horizon and they actually ran larps not on our
campus but they ran larps in the marin headlands okay they like had this cool facility these multi-day larps
one problem is they didn't have any network access so that made co-design interesting but they were like a perfect
test case for playing around with what could a social wearable be if it was fitted into the story world
and it was doing something for not just the one person but the whole group so we worked with them to co-design this
wearable and then we deployed it in this larp and so i'll play this video that my
student made about it [Music]
in 2018 we co-designed a social wearable with a team of larp designers
the device affords a variety of interactions for example expressive ones
you can change the color displayed [Music] or create brightness patterns
[Music] the device also affords competitive
behaviors you can stun people obviously when people can put you into a
state of overload by entering a code on your back in the game narrative when you are
overloaded you are limited in motion and action in fact the device makes you vulnerable
and it gets into overload automatically every now and then and since the wearable makes you vulnerable people can come and help you
they can pat your back to help your overload go by faster or enter another code on your back to
remove it instantly they can also enter a very special code that will make you immune to overloads
altogether a wearable affords a variety of interactions both expressive competitive
and friendly ones
we deployed 15 copies of the wearable in four weekend life event
109 people participated we collected data by enacting researcher characters in the game
and we found something very interesting people were very excited about the vulnerability afforded by the web
it encouraged people to care for one another it made new opportunities for social interactions
that made us think what if we design technology that makes us vulnerable
we feel we just scratched the surface of a really exciting opportunity and we can't wait to continue exploring it
so contrast that with the fitbit right only okay so there's three classes of of
people in this larp the people who got these wearables were called augments and they were not cyborgs they were not
humans but they were augmented humans okay what was interesting is there was an economy in the game and there was
supposed to be these um like wearable technicians you'd have to pay them to get you out of overload
no money changed hands people loved helping the person in the
overload nobody stunned anybody else nobody did anything sneaky the thing they loved about this device
was when someone overloaded and they could go help them it became this like centerpiece of the interactions between
people and like to me that puts a very different data point into the space of
what we could be doing with technology that's worn on the body now
vulnerability obviously comes with risk larpers have this wonderful thing they
do first of all they allow people to set boundaries when they come into a larp i could be touched or i could not be
touched so they have really elaborate safety protocols for people and also they always have a debrief together
where they all talk about how it went and any of what they call bleed where there were strong emotions that came up
so obviously you don't get off the hook for developing this whole socio-technical apparatus around making
people vulnerable but we're brave and intrepid technology designers we shouldn't shy away from
that right like to me this says there's a really interesting direction to go in um
